comments.content: another exception: according to RFC, when responding to 200 OK, ACK's Cseq MUST be the same as the transaction it's acknowledging. (section 13 of RFC)

discussion.content:
Correct answer is C.
ACK is an execption and doesn’t require any response; BTW its Cseq is NOT the same as the INVITE so it belongs to another transaction.

B, The ACK request confirms that the client has received a final
 response to an INVITE request. (ACK is used only with INVITE
 requests.)
In RFC3261 : Regular Transaction: A regular transaction is any transaction with
 a method other than INVITE, ACK, or CANCEL.

choices.A: The ACK method was defined only in RFC 2543 and it has been deprecated.
choices.C: The ACK method is an exception in RFC 3261.
choices.E: The ACK method was replaced with the CANCEL method in RFC 3261.
choices.D: The ACK method is an optional SIP method.
choices.B: The ACK method is part of the INVITE transaction.

questions.question_text:
You are examining a SIP packet. There is no final response to the ACK method.
What is the reason for this?

discussion.content: Training6 state is standby so D is not correct. E is the most accurate statement. Max silence is 1050ms

choices.C: The switchover berpd force command was executed to do a manual failover.
choices.D: The training6 peer is the active node.
choices.A: The two nodes have different health scores.
choices.B: The training1 peer is the standby node.
choices.E: The training6 peer will wait 1050 ms before considering the training1 peer out of service.

discussion.content: D should be correct. registered—Only requests from session agents and registered endpoints are processed. REGISTER allowed from any endpoint.

Answer is wrong .. In Sip-port Peering : [allow anonymous] is either All(any source) - agents only(Session agent) or realm prefix (addr-prefix in realm-config & session agent) ... So answer will be agentsonly

comments.content:
The following are valid values:

all—No ACL is applied and all anonymous connections are allowed.

agents-only—Only requests from configured session agents are processed. The Oracle® Enterprise Session Border Controller responds to all other requests with a forbidden response.

realm-prefix—Only requests from session agents and addresses matching the realm’s address prefix are processed. All other requests are rejected with a 403 (Forbidden) response.

registered—Only requests from session agents and registered endpoints are processed. REGISTER allowed from any endpoint.

registered-prefix—Only requests from session agent and registered endpoint addresses that match the realm’s realm prefix are processed.

The following example shows the allow-anonymous parameter that has been configured to allow only requests from session agents and registered endpoints. All other session agent parameters following the allow-anonymous parameters are omitted for brevity.

questions.question_text:
Your customer would like to allow call attempts only from User Agents (UAs) who have previously registered through the Session Border Controller or who are configured as session agents.
How would you accomplish this?

choices.B: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to prev-registered.
choices.A: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to agents-only.
choices.D: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to registered.
choices.C: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to realm-prefix.
choices.E: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to 403-forbidden.

discussion.content: You can issue the notify berd force on both Active or Standby node. Answer E
Answer is D ... This commend is use to manually switch to active then this should use on standby SBC only ....

comments.content:
notify berpd force
Force a manual switchover between Oracle Communications Session Border Controllers in an HA node, regardless of the Oracle Communications Session Border Controller on which the command is executed.
E is the correct one

choices.B: Active node that no longer has a heartbeat

questions.question_text: From which Session Border Controller node in a high availability (HA) pair, could a network administrator trigger a system switchover manually by issuing the notify berpd force command?

comments.content: I disagree, correct answer is E. It asks for requests that "did not originate from a downstream device" so you need to subtract the number of received packets (client column) to the number of sent packets (server column)
There is 2 recent Columns Server (training1) Recent and Client Recent (Down stream), why would you subtract?

discussion.content:
Correct answer is C (not B).
“Recent” column shows errors for number of seconds listed after the time stamp (2nd line).
PerMax is peak value is the highest “recent”, total is value since last reboot
